text.name: sys_description
text.text: The Sharp X1 is the name given to a series of Japanese microcomputers created by Sharp in 1982. The computers of the time had a read only memory programmed in BASIC, where the X1 directly loaded the interpreter from the cassette with an access To living memory. The whole series included a Zilog Z80A CPU clocked at 4 MHz, with 64 KB of RAM and 3-channel sound. To counter the PC-88, Sharp will release the X1 Turbo with a resolution of 640x400 instead of the original 640x200. Then the X1 Turbo Z with 4,096 colors. And finally a clone which integrated the functionalities of the PC-Engine.
